strings.Value: "The symbol of Pharasma. I believe the Lady of Graves holds Urgathoa in disfavor, and the most faithful of her followers seek out the undead to exterminate..."
"We cannot leave things as they stand. We must find Enneo as soon as possible."
"I have no wish to quarrel with the church of Pharasma."
"Whatever Enneo believes, he has no right to lie and drag people unwittingly into his 'holy war'."

"He's fled. As I expected." {n}Jaethal touches the boxes that hold the merchant's wares. Her moves seem relaxed until you notice that her undead fingers are tense and bent like the claws of a predator.{/n} "It's pointless. Illogical. Those children in the woods could hardly be expected to kill us. Why the performance? There must be something..."

{n}Jaethal freezes, then in an instant she pulls a note from Enneo's wares. She glances at it and silently hands it to you. There's only one phrase on the note — "No way out" — and the image of a spiral comet in place of a signature.{/n}

"True. A conflict of faith, you see. If Enneo is a follower of {g|Pharasma}Pharasma{/g}, he's certainly a cowardly one. First he attacks me while I was unconscious. Then he tries to kill me by proxy... Is there something I'm missing?"

"Thank you for your help. I will not distract you further. I will seek out this amateur backstabber, and will inform you immediately of any news. If the half-blood wants to dispatch me to his Goddess, let him do it in person."

"Of course, the spiral comet is a symbol of Pharasma. Long ago, my goddess managed to break free from the grip of the {g|Pharasma}Lady of Graves{/g}. Ever since, she treats {g|Urgathoa}Urgathoa's{/g} very existence as a personal affront. The {d|Enneo}half-blood{/d} must be a particularly zealous follower of Pharasma... He's already tried to kill me twice."
"You can count on me. I'll hunt that half-blood even beyond death, if needed."

"I think in this case we are dealing with a solitary fanatic. Why kill us by the hands of some elven youths? In any case, your caution is understandable. I had thought I was doing enough to conceal my nature from the public. But It seems I must do more."

"Perhaps he's both fanatic and fool. He struck me down like a coward in the wastelands — only to see me rise again with renewed strength. Then he used those unfortunate youngsters against me — only to fail again. A lack of scruples can be a strength, but not if one lacks will."
